Fig. 2 Fig. 3 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curve of AC (a), 1-Pd/C (b), 1.5-Pd/C (c), 2-Pd/C (d), 2.5-Pd/C (e), 3-Pd/C (f), 4-Pd/ (g), and XRD patterns of Pd/C catalysts (h). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Pd 3d and O 1 s XPS spectra of Pd/C catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Catalytic performance of Pd/AC catalysts with different conditions (reaction time, catalyst dosage, and Pd loading) for the RD reaction. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic performance of Pd/AC catalysts under different temperatures for the RD reaction (a); Comparison of commercial Pd/C catalyst with our catalyst in the disproportionation of rosin (b). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Contour map and response surface graph of the interaction among four factors on the DAA content. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Correlations between DAA content and Pd NPs size (a), crystallite size (b), Pd dispersion (c), Pd loading (d), and Pd0 ratio (e). (Reaction conditions: 0.03 wt%, 270 °C, 120 min, and the atmosphere was nitrogen). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 GC-MS analysis of rosin before and after catalytic disproportionation on: (a) raw rosin, (b) disproportionated rosin; catalyzed by 1.5-Pd/C catalyst; (c) Reaction pathways of RD reaction. This study introduces an efficient Pd/C catalyst for the rosin disproportionation (RD) reaction, a key biomass conversion process. The low-loaded Pd/C catalysts, with 3–6 nm Pd nanoparticles, were synthesized via deposition-precipitation and characterized for their high dispersion of metallic Pd on activated carbon. Optimized using the Box-Behnken design of response surface methodology, the catalyst achieved a 71.36 % maximum DAA yield under optimal conditions (280 °C, 150 min, 0.04 wt% catalyst, 3.00 wt% Pd), surpassing commercial catalysts by 1.27 times with reduced Pd usage. Key factors for catalytic activity included Pd loading, dispersion, particle size, and metallic Pd content. Kinetic studies showed an activation energy of 21.52 kJ/mol for the conversion of abietic acid to dehydroabietic acid, highlighting the superior potential in the RD reaction. Ultraviolet-visible absorption spectra and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analyses elucidated the reaction pathway and mechanism, providing a practical approach to developing high-activity catalysts for industrial RD applications. Graphical Abstract Keywords Pd/C catalyst Rosin disproportionation Process optimization Reaction pathways Response surface methodology Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Resin rosin, a key sustainable natural product derived from forestry, is predominantly produced in China [1]. Primarily composed of rosin acids with a minor fraction of neutrals [2], its susceptibility to oxidation due to double bonds constrains its applications [3]. To enhance its stability and versatility, modifications such as isomerization, disproportionation, hydrogenation, maleation, and esterification are applied. Dehydroabietic acid (DAA), a derivative, finds broad industrial use [4,5]. The transformation to disproportionated rosin offers a cost-effective, renewable resource with significant commercial value. Fig. 1 depicts the modification process. The RD reaction is an oxidation-reduction process in which a segment of the conjugated double bonds in AA loses two hydrogen atoms, forming a stable benzene ring structure known as DAA. Concurrently, another portion of AA molecules gains two or four hydrogen atoms, resulting in the formation of dihydroabietic acid or tetrahydroabietic acid, respectively [6]. Catalysis is essential for this reaction, with the catalytic performance profoundly affecting both the reaction efficiency and product quality [7]. Among the various RD catalysts, including sulfide, iodide, non-precious metal, and precious metal catalysts [8], the Pd/C catalyst is particularly favored in industrial applications due to its high activity, lower operating temperature requirements, and superior product quality in RD reactions [9]. However, the scarcity of palladium (with concentrations < 3 ng/g in the Earth’s crust) and its high cost render Pd/C catalysts expensive [10]. Therefore, improving RD reaction performance and reducing catalyst costs are crucial objectives. Extensive research has focused on elucidating the reaction pathways and improving the catalytic performance of Pd/C catalysts in RD reaction. Mostafalu et al. produced spherical Pd/C catalysts with particle sizes from 10 to 45 nm via liquid phase reduction, achieving a 70 % yield of DAA in disproportionated rosin under optimized conditions [11]. Zeng et al. enhanced Pd utilization by modifying AC with maleic acid, sodium citrate, and salicylic acid, forming strong Pd complexes that resulted in superior catalytic activity and production of disproportionated rosin meeting forestry first-grade standards [12]. Gu et al. increased the specific surface area of AC through nitric acid pretreatment and prepared Pd/C catalysts at various vacuum drying temperatures using wet impregnation; the catalyst dried at 443 K exhibited the highest Pd dispersion (23.60 %), specific surface area (1057 m²/g), and DAA content (64.15 %), underscoring the influence of strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) on catalyst performance [13]. Despite these efforts, Pd/C catalysts for RD often exhibit low catalytic activity and high precious metal content ( Table 1). Research has primarily focused on support modification and reaction kinetics [14–16]. There is a lack of literature on low-loading Pd/C catalysts that maintain high catalytic activity, and the structure-activity relationship in RD is not well understood. The mechanisms of AA hydrogenation and dehydrogenation are not well established, impeding the development of more efficient Pd/C catalysts. Understanding the reaction pathways and intermediates is crucial for reducing precious metal usage and developing more efficient catalysts. In catalysis, the efficiency of the RD process is profoundly influenced by various reaction-intrinsic parameters and catalyst characteristics. A comprehensive review of the literature reveals that reaction temperature, duration, catalyst dosage, and Pd loading are the pivotal factors that significantly modulate catalytic performance. The response surface methodology (RSM), and specifically the Box-Behnken Design (BBD), is widely recognized for its ability to define the optimal operational parameters for RD processes by assessing the effects of these multiple factors [19,20]. BBD is noted for its effectiveness and practicality in statistical experimental design, due to its ability to examine multiple variables concurrently within a single experimental setup and its requirement for fewer experimental trials compared to other strategies [21,22]. Additionally, BBD can estimate response functions at intermediate levels without the need for direct experimental probing [23]. Although BBD has been extensively applied in analogous contexts, its application in optimizing and modeling the Pd/C-catalyzed RD reaction has not been explored. This study, therefore, employs the BBD experimental design model to determine the optimized conditions for the RD process, addressing a significant research gap. This work successfully synthesized a range of Pd/C catalysts with low Pd loadings ranging from 1.00–4.00 wt%, employing a deposition-precipitation method. These catalysts exhibited high activity in the RD reaction under mild conditions with mechanical agitation. Characterization techniques including high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were employed to characterize the catalysts structure and chemical properties. These characterizations established the correlation between catalyst structure and catalytic activity, shedding light on the underlying catalytic mechanisms. A comprehensive investigation of the RD process, encompassing reaction temperature, time, catalyst dosage, and Pd loading, was performed using a three-level, four-factor BBD based on RSM. Furthermore, ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) spectroscopy and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) were employed for the quantification and qualitative analysis of the disproportionation products, delineating the reaction pathway. This research focuses on elucidating the structure of Pd/C catalysts and optimizing the RD reaction conditions, providing a theoretical foundation for their industrial application. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and chemicals The detailed materials and chemicals information were shown in Supplementary Material. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Palladium-loaded AC supports with Pd contents ranging from 1.00 wt% to 4.00 wt% were synthesized via the deposition-precipitation method with palladium (II) nitrate (Pd(NO3)2) as the metal precursor. The preparation procedure is as follows ( Scheme 1) and described in detail within in Support Material. The resulting Pd/C catalysts were labeled according to their increasing Pd loadings as 1-Pd/C, 1.5-Pd/C, 2-Pd/C, 2.5-Pd/C, 3-Pd/C, and 4-Pd/C. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Detailed information regarding inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and N2 adsorption-desorption measurements can be found in the Supplementary Material. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation A total of 100 g of raw rosin was accurately weighed and then crushed into a nitrogen-purged three-necked flask, which was equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a thermometer. The flask was heated to melt the rosin with continuous magnetic stirring. At a temperature of 230 °C, 10–40 mg (0.01–0.04 wt%) of Pd/C catalyst was uniformly incorporated into the molten rosin. The reaction temperature was set to 270 °C and maintained throughout the duration of the process. Samples were collected at intervals of 30 min using a pipette for subsequent analysis. Detailed information on the catalytic tests and a schematic diagram of the disproportionation reaction evaluation setup (Fig. S1) for rosin can be found in the Support Material. 2.5 GC-MS analysis To ascertain the principal constituents and track the conversion of AA to DAA, as well as to assess the yield of DAA after disproportionation, both the raw and disproportionated rosin were subjected to a thorough gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) analysis. The sample preparation included a methylation step using tetramethylammonium hydroxide in methanol, which is crucial for analyzing the polar and high-boiling compounds present in rosin, such as abietic acid. This step enhances the volatility and reduces the polarity of these compounds, facilitating their analysis. Comprehensive details regarding the equipment and experimental parameters are furnished in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pd/C catalysts 3.1.1 Structural characterization of Pd/C catalysts The Pd content in the as-prepared Pd/C catalysts was quantified using ICP-AES. Table 2 shows that the Pd loadings in the six samples match the targeted concentrations of 1.00 wt%, 1.50 wt%, 2.00 wt%, 2.50 wt%, 3.00 %, and 4.00 %, respectively. These findings confirm the successful synthesis of the Pd/C catalysts. The specific surface area (S BET), total pore volume (TPV), mean pore size (MPS), crystallite size, and dispersion of Pd/C catalysts were measured and are summarized in Table 2. An increase in Pd loading resulted in a significant reduction in the S BET and TPV of the Pd/C catalysts, from 1605.10 m2/g and 1.38 cm3/g to 667.23 m2/g and 0.65 cm3/g, respectively. This reduction is due to the aggregation of Pd NPs on the AC support surface or within its pores [24]. The elevated Pd loading on AC enhances the number of active sites, thereby improving catalyst activity [25]. To elucidate the surface morphology and microstructure of the synthesized Pd/C catalysts, TEM images and EDS mappings are depicted in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2. The images display numerous distinct darker Pd NPs against a lighter AC background, confirming high-density dispersion of Pd NPs on AC. To determine the average particles size of the catalysts, 200 particles were randomly selected for analysis, and the findings are shown in Fig. 2(a-f). The results demonstrate that Pd NPs are highly dispersed on the AC surface, with average sizes ranging from 3.32 to 5.98 nm. An increase in Pd loading results in larger Pd NPs and a wider size distribution. The average Pd sizes, calculated from Scherrer equation (Table 2), align with TEM observations. Exceeding a 2.00 wt% Pd loading results in significant aggregation of Pd species, reducing dispersion. HAADF-STEM images reveal lattice distances of 0.222–0.226 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of Pd NPs [27]. EDS mapping confirms the uniform distribution of C, O, and Pd elements across the AC surface (Fig. S2) [28]. This uniform Pd dispersion is pivotal for maximizing active sites and enhancing catalytic activity in the disproportionation reaction. The specific surface areas and pore size distribution of AC and Pd/C catalysts were examined using nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. Fig. 3(a-g) display the corresponding pore size distribution, with structural parameters provided in Table 2. Both the AC and Pd/C catalysts display typical Type IV isotherms with H2 hysteresis loops at relative pressures of 0.6 < P/P 0 < 0.9, indicative of mesoporous structures [29,30]. The pore size distribution, derived from the Density Functional Theory (DFT) model, reveals that the pore diameters are concentrated in 1–10 nm range and are evenly distributed across all samples. After Pd loading, the shape of the adsorption isotherm shape was maintained, but the gas adsorbed decreased, suggesting a reduction in mesopore and total pore volume. The AC possesses a surface area and pore volume of 1605.10 m²/g and 1.38 cm³ /g, respectively, which is conducive to Pd species dispersion. However, with increasing Pd loading, the surface area and pore volume of the Pd/C catalysts decrease in the following order: 1-Pd/C (1568.77 m²/g, 1.14 cm³/g) > 1.5-Pd/C (1482.63 m²/g, 1.02 cm³/g) > 2-Pd/C (1229.15 m²/g, 0.95 cm³/g) > 2.5-Pd/C (1081.50 m²/g, 0.85 cm³/g) > 3-Pd/C (764.85 m²/g, 0.75 cm³/g) > 4-Pd/C (667.23 m²/g, 0.65 cm³/g). This trend suggests that Pd particles, which are relatively large compared to the mesopore size, may partially occupy and block some mesopores within the support. Nevertheless, the large BET surface area of AC indicates a high number of active catalytic sites, aiding adsorption and activation [31]. Fig. 3(h) presents the XRD patterns of the Pd/C catalysts, showing a broad peak at 26.0° for the carbon support (PDF #75–0444). Four distinct peaks corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Pd (PDF #00–005–0681) are also observed. At low loadings, the Pd characteristic peak is barely visible, indicating small, highly dispersed Pd NPs particles on the AC surface [32]. Above 2.00 wt% Pd loading, a pronounced peak at 40.1° appears, corresponding to the (111) planes of Pd. The predominance of the Pd (111) face is crucial for rosin disproportionation. The intensity of this peak increases with higher Pd loadings, indicating effective deposition. The XRD data align with the ICP-AES results in Table 2. Pd NPs, calculated from the full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) of the Pd (111) peak at 40.1° using the Scherrer equation, increase in the order: 1-Pd/C < 1.5-Pd/C < 2-Pd/C < 2.5-Pd/C < 3-Pd/C < 4-Pd/C. Pd dispersion values, determined from crystallite sizes, are 38.17 %, 37.67 %, 36.81 %, 33.73 %, 34.55 %, and 33.13 % for the 1-Pd/C to 4-Pd/C catalysts, respectively (Table 2). Although peak overlapping with the carbon support may affect accuracy, the trend in crystallite sizes and Pd dispersion is consistent with TEM findings. 3.1.2 XPS analysis of Pd/C catalysts XPS analysis of the Pd 3d and O 1 s levels was conducted to investigate the surface electronic configurations of the Pd/C catalysts, with results detailed in Fig. 4 and Table S1. The deconvoluted XPS spectra exposed two pairs of peaks for Pd/C series. Peaks at 335.20–336.26 eV and 340.33–341.29 eV, indicative of metallic Pd (Pd0), correspond to the Pd 3d 5/2 and 3d 3/2 orbitals, respectively. A less intense set of peaks at 336.21–337.56 eV and 341.35–342.78 eV are assigned to Pd2+ species, originating from the same orbitals [33,34]. A systematic increase in Pd0 intensity and a corresponding decrease in Pd2+ intensity were observed across the 1-Pd/C to 4-Pd/C series. A higher Pd0 to Pd2+ ratio and increased peak intensity suggest enhanced catalytic activity due to the reduced Pd0 state [35]. Additionally, the Pd0 3d 5/2 XPS peaks shifted towards higher binding energies (Table S1), indicating a strengthened interaction between metallic Pd and the AC support. This interaction, supported by literature, implies the formation of negatively charged Pd0 species (Pd0-Vo) through electron transfer via the SMSI mechanism [36,37], enhancing H2 adsorption and activation [38]. Consequently, increased Pd loading correlates with a higher density of Pd0-Vo species, which is associated with improved catalytic activity for the RD reaction. Oxygen vacancies are acknowledged for their essential role in oxygen species absorption. To elucidate the surface oxygen species, O 1 s XPS analysis was conducted, with the spectra presented in Fig. 4(g-i). Two distinct oxygen species were identified: the predominant peak at 531.71–532.29 eV corresponds to bulk AC lattice oxygen (Oα), and the minor shoulder peak at 532.98–533.46 eV corresponds to surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oβ) [39,40]. The Oβ/(Oα+Oβ) ratio varies from 38.20 % to 58.33 %, peaking at 58.33 % for the 2.5-Pd/C, indicating a high chemisorbed oxygen content. These findings imply a rich presence of surface oxygen species on Pd/C catalysts, consistent with their efficacy in activating water and oxygen [41,42]. Literature suggests that oxygen vacancies on the AC support can produce adsorbed atomic oxygen, which, due to its high mobility, participates actively in the redox cycles of the RD reaction, significantly affecting the oxidation and reduction properties of the supported Pd species [39]. Therefore, the capability of the Pd/C catalysts to activate the chemisorbed oxygen is pivotal to their catalytic activity, complementing their oxygen generation capacity. Chemisorbed oxygen is more readily activated by metallic Pd than by cationic Pd. Metallic Pd NPs, with their strong oxygen activation capability, act as active sites for rosin catalytic oxidation. The activated oxygen then participates in the hydrogenation and dehydrogenation reactions of rosin. The SMSI effect, which imparts a negative charge to metallic Pd NPs, along with the abundance of chemisorbed oxygen, likely accounts for the high catalytic activity observed over the Pd/C catalysts [43,44]. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Pd/C catalyst in RD reaction Reaction time, temperature, catalyst dosage, and Pd loading are paramount factors affecting the RD reaction. This section meticulously examines their influence on both AA conversion and DAA selectivity. The experimental parameters were adjusted over a wide range: reaction times spanned 30–180 minutes, temperatures ranged from 230 to 270 °C, catalyst dosages varied from 0.01 to 0.04 wt%, and Pd loadings were set between 1.00 and 4.00 wt%. This broad spectrum was used to comprehensively assess their impact on the reaction. The catalytic performance of catalysts 1-Pd/C, 1.5-Pd/C, 2-Pd/C, 2.5-Pd/C, 3-Pd/C, and 4-Pd/C under these conditions was systematically assessed, with the findings depicted in Fig. 5. 3.2.1 Effect of reaction time on catalytic performance Fig. 5 depicts the time-dependent catalytic activity of Pd/C catalysts in the RD reaction. The DAA content for all six catalysts increased markedly within the first 120 min, after which it stabilized until 180 min. In contrast, the AA content diminished over time, culminating in complete conversion. At the optimal conditions of 270 °C, a 2.00 wt% Pd loading, 0.04 wt% catalyst dosage, a reaction time of 180 min, and under a nitrogen atmosphere, the DAA and AA yields reached their maxima of 71.13 % and 0 % (theoretically), respectively. These findings underscore the advantage of extended reaction time for the hydrogenation/dehydrogenation processes of rosin, ensuring complete AA conversion and maximizing DAA selectivity. 3.2.2 Effect of catalyst dosage on catalytic performance Fig. 5 vividly illustrates the effect of Pd/C catalyst dosage on the RD reaction. A pronounced enhancement in both AA conversion and DAA selectivity was observed with an increase in catalyst dosage from 0.01 wt% to 0.02 wt%. For dosages above 0.02 wt%, the reaction was minimally affected for all catalysts except the 1-Pd/C, which continued to exhibit increased DAA selectivity. Notably, the DAA selectivity for the 1-Pd/C catalyst peaked at 27.16 %, 54.15 %, 51.32 %, and 62.8 % at dosages of 0.01 wt%, 0.02 wt%, 0.03 wt%, and 0.04 wt%, respectively, under the conditions of 270 °C and a reaction time of 180 min. The accelerated reaction rate and the shortened equilibrium stabilization period to one hour with increased dosage suggest a substantial increase in hydrogen-spillover active sites, essential for the RD reaction. Collectively, these results suggest that a 0.02 wt% Pd/C catalyst dosage strikes an optimal balance between cost and catalytic efficiency. 3.2.3 Effect of Pd loading on catalytic performance To deepen our understanding of the dehydrogenation mechanism over the synthesized catalysts, the effect of Pd loading on catalytic performance was systematically investigated. As depicted in Fig. 5, under conditions of 270 °C, a 2-h reaction time, and a 0.03 wt% catalyst dosage, the DAA content rose significantly from 50.19 % to 61.51 % as Pd loading increased from 1.0 wt% to 2.5 wt%, while the AA content correspondingly fell from 3.41 % to −0.38 %. This improvement in catalytic performance is attributed to the increased density of active sites with higher Pd loadings, which facilitates better reactant contact with active centers, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. However, further increasing the Pd loading to 3.0 wt% and 4.0 wt% resulted in a notable decrease in DAA content after reaching a peak 61.51 %. Specifically, the DAA content dropped to 55.66 % and 57.55 % for the 3.0 wt% and 4.0 wt% Pd loadings, respectively. This trend underscores the correlation between higher Pd loadings and larger Pd/C particle sizes, associated with reduced dispersion, as evidenced by the data in Table 2 and visually represented in Fig. 2. Beyond a threshold, these changes induce Pd NPs instability and agglomeration, inevitably compromises catalytic efficiency. Additionally, although 3-Pd/C and 4-Pd/C possess the highest contents of metallic Pd contents, their catalytic activities are not the most superior, suggesting that catalytic performance cannot be fully explained by the Pd0 contents. Previous literature has demonstrated that oxygen vacancies, as a type of defect structure, can effectively alter the electronic structure and coordination environment, thereby enhancing catalytic performance [45]. Oxygen-rich vacancies not only facilitate hydrogen spillover but also significantly enhance hydrogen activation and dissociation, which aligns with the superior RD reaction activation ability of the 2.5-Pd/C catalysts, known for their highest Oβ content. These findings are supported by the work of Li et al. [46], who reported enhanced reactant activation due to the presence of abundant carbon defects. 3.2.4 Effect of temperature on catalytic performance Chemical reactions are intricately linked to temperature, which is a critical factor in providing the necessary activation energy. The influence of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of Pd/C catalysts in the RD reaction is presented in Fig. 6(a). The experimental parameters were set as follows: a catalyst dosage of 0.03 wt%, a reaction time of 2 h, a Pd loading of 2.00 wt%, and a nitrogen atmosphere. The results show that DAA content increased in tandem with the elevation of temperature. Specifically, the DAA content dramatically increased from 7.92 % to 54.52 % as the temperature was raised from 230 to 270 °C. The reaction rate exhibited the most pronounced variation between 230 and 250 °C, after which the rate of increase moderated, indicating that 270 °C is the optimal temperature for the RD reaction. Previous studies indicate that the activation energy for the dehydrogenation of AA is higher than that for its hydrogenation [47,48], suggesting that dehydrogenation becomes the dominant reaction pathway at elevated temperatures. Moreover, dehydrogenation reactions are reversible, endothermic, and typically involve an increase in the number of molecules. Therefore, increasing the reaction temperature not only favors the endothermic dehydrogenation process but also enhances the selectivity of the RD reaction and the overall dehydrogenation pathway. This temperature effect is crucial for optimizing the reaction conditions to achieve high yields of the desired product, DAA. 3.2.5 Comparison of catalytic performance with commercial catalyst To underscore the outstanding catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts, a comparative analysis was conducted between the 2-Pd/C catalyst and a commercial Pd/C catalyst (4.00 wt%) for the RD reaction. Fig. 6(b) shows that our 2-Pd/C catalyst outperformed a commercial one under standard conditions (reaction temperature of 270 °C, a reaction time of 180 minutes, a catalyst dosage of 0.04 wt%, and a nitrogen atmosphere), reducing AA and boosting DAA selectivity. It increased activity by 1.27 times with half the Pd, enhancing cost-efficiency and sustainability. Additionally, our catalyst offers superior value in terms of cost-performance compared to catalysts previously reported in the literature (Table 1). Analysis of the data in Fig. 5 reveals that all Pd/C catalysts synthesized by our team, with varying Pd loadings, exhibited remarkable catalytic activity. The disproportionated rosin products meet the stringent requirements for special-grade disproportionated rosin as specified in the forestry standard LY/T 1357–2008, which mandates a minimum dehydroabietic acid content of 52 % and an abietic acid content not exceeding 0.1 %. These comparative results indicate that our catalysts not only display superior catalytic performance but also offer lower preparation costs, positioning them as highly promising candidates for practical applications in industrial RD processes. 3.3 Optimal RD process via RSM (Response surface method) Single-factor experiments indicate that the optimal conditions for maximizing DAA content are a reaction temperature of 270 °C, a duration of 120 min, a catalyst dosage of 0.03 wt%, and a Pd loading of 0.02 wt%. However, the resulting DAA yield is unsatisfactory, and these experiments fail to address the complex factor interactions that affect DAA selectivity in the RD reaction. RSM, particularly the BBD, provides a more nuanced approach to optimizing parameters efficiently. This technique uncovers the mathematical relationships between DAA content and the influencing factors, including their interactions, which is crucial for enhancing DAA selectivity [49]. Building on the single-factor results, we established operational ranges for reaction temperature (260–280 °C), time (90–150 min), catalyst dosage (20–30 mg), and Pd loading (0.02–0.04 g). Using the BBD model with Design Expert 13.0 software, we systematically refined the experimental conditions and analyzed the factor interactions to improve the catalytic efficiency for the RD reaction. 3.3.1 Determination of RSM factors In the RSM, four independent variables were identified: reaction temperature (A), time (B), catalyst addition amount (C), and Pd loading (D). These variables were each examined at three distinct levels, coded as −1 (low), 0 (middle), and 1 (high). Table 3 summarizes the actual and coded levels for these factors. The DAA content was set as the response variable. Notably, the BBD incorporated 27 experiments, including three central point replicates to estimate the pure error of the sum of squares. The dependent variable was DAA content, with independent variables being reaction temperature, time, catalyst dosage, and Pd loading. A mathematical model equation was formulated using the BBD optimization to forecast the optimal conditions for the RD reaction. This model serves as a predictive tool, allowing for process refinement to achieve the desired DAA content by considering the complex interactions among the variables. 3.3.2 The DAA yield response surface experiment and variance analysis To achieve the most accurate regression model, second-order polynomials were used to fit the experimental data. Design-Expert software version 13 facilitated the design, analysis, and optimization of the trials for the response surface experiment. The model coefficients, indicative of precision and effectiveness, were derived from fitting the polynomial equation to the data. The outcomes of the RD reaction process, utilizing the BBD and RSM experimental designs, are detailed in Table S2. The following multivariate quadratic response surface regression model is built by Design-Expert software 13 from Table S2: (1) η (%) = 55.01 + 4.34 A + 0.5925B + 5.42 C + 3.51D + 0.0250AB + 1.27AC + 0.8250AD + 0.5850BC + 0.1775BD -0.9775CD - 2.86A 2 + 1.23B 2 + 5.71C 2 - 2.67D 2 where η represents the response value (DAA content, %), A denotes reaction temperature, B represents time, C and D signifies the addition and Pd loading, respectively. The linear factors of A, B, C, and D positively influence DAA content, indicating that increased reaction temperatures, extended durations, higher catalyst dosages, and greater Pd loadings enhance DAA selectivity. Likewise, the interactions among these factors also positively affect the DAA content. Thus, optimizing conditions to maximize DAA selectivity necessitates accounting for these combined effects. Table 4 presents the experimental results and the variance analysis fitted to the quadratic regression model equation. (Note: SS—Sum of squares; DF—Degrees of freedom; MS—Mean square. R 2 = 0.9428, R adj 2 = 0.8761, R pre 2 = 0.6795, C.V.% = 4.31, Adeq Precision = 14.7876.) The analysis of variance (ANOVA) for the quadratic model detailed in Table 4 indicates that the model F-value of 14.13 and a p-value < 0.0001, confirming the statistical significance of the model. Values of “Prob > F” below 0.0500 indicate significant model terms. In this case, the fitted R 2 = 0.9428, R adj 2 = 0.8761, and low C.V.% (4.31 < 15) also suggested that the model fit the experimental data well. Adeq Precision, which assesses the signal-to-noise ratio, is favorable with a value greater than 4.0. The Adeq Precision of this model is 14.7876 suggests an excellent fit. The Lack of Fit value of 0.2028 over 0.05 verified the validity of the model. The difference between R adj 2 (0.8761) and R pre 2 (0.6795) is less than 0.2, signifying that the model fits well with the data. ANOVA reveals that the first-order terms A, C, and D have p-value of < 0.0001, but the p-value of B = 0.4087, indicating their significant impact on the response variable, except for time. Interaction terms of AB, AC, AD, BC, BD, and CD also show non-significant effects. Moreover, the quadratic terms A 2 , C 2 , D 2 are found to have significant impacts. Therefore, the relative influence of each factor on the DAA content under the RD reaction conditions is ranked as follows: C (Addition) > A (Temperature) > D (Pd loading) > B (Time). Fig. S3(a) presents a comparison between the predicted values and the experimental findings of the quadratic regression model for the RD reaction. The plot illustrates a linear representation where the predicted model values are plotted against the experimental values, with scattered dots that deviate from the line, thereby validating the quadratic regression model. The closer the data points align with the line, the more precise the model's fit to the data. Fig. S3(b) exhibits the results of the experimental residual analysis, depicting a near-linear distribution of experimental residuals without significant outliers. This confirms the robustness of the selected model, as experimental results closely align with expected values, effectively capturing the interplay between the factors and the response values [50,51]. 3.3.3 Factor interaction response surface analysis The variance analysis revealed that the catalyst addition amount exerts a more significant influence on DAA content than temperature, Pd loading, and time. Fig. 7 presents contour plots and 3D response surfaces for factor interactions AB, AC, AD, BC, BD, and CD, elucidating how independent variables impact DAA yield [52]. Horizontal contours in these plots signify a strong main effect, while elliptical or saddle-shaped contours indicate significant interactions [53]. Steep slopes within the response surface plot suggest a more substantial influence on DAA content [54]. The color-coding on the surface plot denotes different DAA content ranges: red for above 60 %, yellow for 50–60 %, and green for below 50 %. Fig. 7(b) clearly shows that the interaction between A (temperature) and C (catalyst addition amount) significantly influences DAA content. With time (B) and Pd loading (D) fixed at 120 min and 0.02 g, respectively, increasing A from 250 °C to 290 °C and C from 20 to 40 mg leads to a consistent increase in DAA content. Analysis of the contour lines and 3D response surface maps indicates that catalyst addition amount (C) has a greater influence than temperature (A), followed by Pd loading (D) and time (B). Moreover, the A-C interaction significantly affects DAA content more than other interactions. This comprehensive analysis provides valuable insights into the relative importance of each factor and their interactions, guiding the optimization of the reaction conditions for higher DAA production. 3.3.4 Verification of the optimization model The quadratic regression response model identified optimal parameters for adsorption: 280 °C temperature, 150-minute duration, 40 mg (0.04 wt%) catalyst dosage, and 0.03 g (3.00 wt%) Pd loading. These parameters were refined for practical application to ascertain the most favorable conditions for the RD reaction. To validate the model predictions, three parallel experiments were conducted under these optimal conditions, yielding an average DAA content of 71.36 % (Table S3). The relative deviation of 1.5 % is well within the standard deviation of 2.4 %, confirming the reliability of the optimal process conditions predicted and optimized using the quadratic regression response model. 3.4 Matching relationship between structure and performance of Pd/C catalysts To verify the impact of catalyst structure on catalytic performance in the RD reaction, Pearson correlation analysis was performed. Fig. 8 displays the correlations between DAA yield and catalyst parameters, including Pd NPs size, crystallite size, Pd loading, dispersion, and Pd0 ratio. A positive association was found with Pd NPs size, crystallite size, Pd loading, and Pd0 ratio, whereas a negative correlation existed with dispersion. The Pearson correlation coefficients ranged from 0.812 for crystallite size to 0.990 for Pd loading, highlighting the influence of Pd loading, dispersion, Pd0 ratio, and particle size on catalytic activity. Increased Pd loading promotes nanoparticle growth and agglomeration (Fig. 3), detrimental to dispersion but compensates with additional active sites. Higher Pd NPs size and optimized Pd0 ratio significantly enhanced catalytic efficiency. Under conditions: 0.04 wt% dosage, 280 °C, 150 min, nitrogen as the protective gas, the 3-Pd/C catalyst maximizes DAA yield in disproportionated rosin (71.36 %), validating our analytical approach. 3.5 Reaction kinetics of rosin disproportionation RD reaction is a multifaceted process encompassing both concurrent and sequential reactions. In our investigation, the primary objective was to achieve the conversion of AA into DAA, which served as the basis for our kinetic analysis. We formulated macroscopic kinetic models and determined the corresponding kinetic parameters. To minimize the influence of diffusion, the catalyst particles were ground to a size range of 10–20 μm, and the stirring speed was elevated to 1000 r/min, thus making chemical kinetics the dominant factor in the reaction. Experiments were conducted under precise conditions, with temperatures set at 503.15, 513.15, 523.15, and 533.15 K, and the reaction time was prolonged up to 210 minutes. Using a standardized 0.03 wt% 2-Pd/C catalyst, samples were collected at regular intervals within a temperature range of 230–260 °C. The variations in DAA concentration were measured employing UV-Vis spectroscopy and GC-MS, providing us with intrinsic kinetic insights. The apparent activation energy was subsequently derived from Eqs. (2) and (3) [55]. (2) C t − C 0 = − k 0 t (3) lnk = − E a RT + ln A Where C t is the content of DAA, C 0 is the content of DAA in raw rosin, t is reaction time (min), k 0 is zero-order k 0 is the reaction rate constant (min−1); k is the temperature-independent factor, E a is the activation energy (kJ mol−1), R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J mol K−1), T is the solution temperature (K) and A is the pre-exponential factor [56]. The kinetic parameters and profiles for the Pd/C catalyst at various temperatures, as presented in Fig. 9(a) and Table S4, distinctly illustrate the zero-order kinetics characteristic of the dehydrogenation of AA [57,58]. The apparent activation energy, determined using the Arrhenius equation (refer to Fig. 9(b)), is calculated to be 21.52 kJ/mol. This value is comparatively lower than those documented in earlier studies for Pd/C catalysts in similar reactions [59], suggesting that our catalyst potentially enhances the catalytic efficacy of the rosin disproportionation reaction by lowering the activation energy threshold. 3.6 Reaction pathways of rosin disproportionation reaction GC-MS analysis revealed the compositional changes in rosin before and after catalytic disproportionation, as shown in Fig. 10(a-b) and detailed in Tables S5-S6. The raw rosin contained AA at 34.25 %, palustric acid at 20.35 %, and 1-phenanthrenecarboxylic acid at 35.75 %, alongside trace amounts of DAA at 3.38 %, longifolene at 1.11 %, and retinoic acid at 1.11 %. After catalytic disproportionation, the product profile shifted significantly, with DAA constituting 52 %, 1-phenanthrenecarboxylic acid at 35.92 %, and a significantly reduced AA content to 1.91 %. The dehydrogenation of AA and the isomerization of palustric acid took place, yielding DAA as the principal product of the disproportionation reaction, with AA nearly eliminated under more reactive conditions [60]. Notably, the absence of dihydroabietic and tetrahydroabietic acids in the disproportionated rosin suggests a marked preference for dehydrogenation over hydrogenation under the applied catalytic conditions, with a negligible hydroabietic acid yield. This observation highlights the 100 % selective conversion of AA to DAA in the RD process. Previous studies indicates that raw rosin constituents, including neoabietic acid, palustric acid, levopimaric acid, and abietic acid, readily isomerize to abietic acid upon heating through hydrogen atom transfer [61,62]. The highly reactive conjugated double bond in AA molecule can readily absorb one mole of hydrogen to form dihydroabietic acid. Subsequently, further hydrogenation of the remaining double bond is significantly hindered, and only a minor proportion of dihydroabietic acid can react with hydrogen to form tetrahydroabietic acid. The Pd/C catalyst enhances AA dehydrogenation selectivity [63]. The reaction pathway for AA to DAA, as depicted in Fig. 10(c). Initially, dihydroabietic acid forms as an intermediate after the cleavage of one CC bond within the conjugated diene and subsequent hydrogenation in one C6 ring. Then, through two distinct pathways, the four hydrogen atoms in the adjacent C6 ring are removed, culminating in the formation of the final DAA product. This comprehensive analysis provides a clear understanding of the reaction mechanisms involved in the catalytic disproportionation of rosin, underscoring the efficiency of the Pd/C catalyst in directing the reaction towards the desired product profile. 4 Conclusion In this work, a series of Pd/C catalysts with low Pd loading and different Pd NPs size were successfully fabricated via deposition-precipitation strategies for the RD reaction. Multiple characterization results showed that Pd species, most Pd0 and minor PdOx, highly dispersed on AC, with an average size of Pd NPs in the range of 3–6 nm. More structural defects and oxygen vacancies on the Pd/C catalyst surface increased the electron density around Pd species and enhanced the activation of chemisorbed oxygen, which is beneficial to the RD reaction. The effect of reaction time, temperature, Pd loading, and catalyst dosage on catalytic performance was extensively investigated. Maximum conversion of AA reached 100 % and 71.13 % yield to DAA under the conditions with a Pd loading of 2.00 wt%, reaction time of 180 min, temperature of 270 °C, and catalyst dosage of 0.04 %. Compared to commercial catalyst, activity increased by 1.27 times with a 50 % reduction in Pd, conserving precious metals. Maximum DAA content (71.36 %) occurred at the following operating factor optimum values based on RSM-BBD: temperature of 280 °C, a time of 150 min, a catalyst dosage of 40 mg (0.04 wt%), and a Pd loading of 0.03 g (3.00 wt%). Pd loading, dispersion, particle size, and metallic Pd contents were identified as primary determinants of Pd/C catalytic activity. Kinetic studies confirmed an activation energy of 21.52 kJ/mol for the AA to DAA conversion, validating Pd/C catalyst was a very promising catalyst for the RD reaction. Ultimately, both qualitative and quantitative analyses of rosin and disproportionated rosin were conducted using UV–vis and GC-MS, thereby clarifying the reaction pathway and catalytic mechanism of the RD reaction catalyzed by Pd/C. coredata.dc:description: This study introduces an efficient Pd/C catalyst for the rosin disproportionation (RD) reaction, a key biomass conversion process. The low-loaded Pd/C catalysts, with 3–6 nm Pd nanoparticles, were synthesized via deposition-precipitation and characterized for their high dispersion of metallic Pd on activated carbon. Optimized using the Box-Behnken design of response surface methodology, the catalyst achieved a 71.36 % maximum DAA yield under optimal conditions (280 °C, 150 min, 0.04 wt% catalyst, 3.00 wt% Pd), surpassing commercial catalysts by 1.27 times with reduced Pd usage. Key factors for catalytic activity included Pd loading, dispersion, particle size, and metallic Pd content. Kinetic studies showed an activation energy of 21.52 kJ/mol for the conversion of abietic acid to dehydroabietic acid, highlighting the superior potential in the RD reaction. Ultraviolet-visible absorption spectra and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analyses elucidated the reaction pathway and mechanism, providing a practical approach to developing high-activity catalysts for industrial RD applications.
